physical_description: Script, One item: Cursive.
note: One item: Latin.|Explicit, One item: Jean de Thourotte, châtelain de Thourotte (Oise) and seigneur d'Honnecourt-sur-Escaut (Nord) and of Allibaudieres (Aube) acknowledges receipt of his wages of 37 pounds and 10 sous given him by representatives of the King of France.|Docket: Jean de Thourotte, châtelain de Thourotte (Oise) and seigneur d'Honnecourt-sur-Escaut (Nord) and of Allibaudieres (Aube) acknowledges receipt of his wages of 37 pounds and 10 sous given him by representatives of the King of France.
acknowledgements: Riccardo Famiglietti kindly identified persons and places in this document.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
former_owner_as_recorded: Ink stamp of Roy G. Fitzgerald (1875-1962); sold at Parke-Bernet (6 November 1963)?; acquired in 1991 from P. Pirages.
former_owner_label: Roy G. Fitzgerald;Phillip J. Pirages Fine Books & Manuscripts
note: One item: Latin.|One item: In the property exchange, Juliana gives her fief in the parish of Seuilly and in the castellany of Montsoreau to Philippa for an annual rent of 60 sous on the péage of Bizay (Maine-et-Loire). Philippe de Bernezay was apparently the first wife (less possibly the daughter) of Guillaume de Marmande, brother of Bouchard, lord of Marmande, in whose presence this action took place; Bouchard and Guilluame had a sister, Julienne, the other party to the action, who was dame de Bernezay and wife of Aimery Odart.|Explicit, One item: Exchange of property in the presence of Bouchard, lord of Marmande (Vienne, commune de Velleches) and of Trèves (Maine-et-Loire), transacted by Philippa, dame du Coudray, and Juliana, dame de Bernezay.|Docket: Exchange of property in the presence of Bouchard, lord of Marmande (Vienne, commune de Velleches) and of Trèves (Maine-et-Loire), transacted by Philippa, dame du Coudray, and Juliana, dame de Bernezay.
acknowledgements: Riccardo Famiglietti kindly identified persons and places in this document.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
former_owner_as_recorded: Manuscript purchased in Madrid by a former owner (per label); gift in 1959 of Mrs. Monica Franklyn of central New Jersey.
physical_description: Other decoration, f. 1r-v: 2-line and 1-line initials in red and blue with penwork flourishing respectively in purple and in red.|Script, f. 1r-v: Gothic.|Layout, f. 1r-v: 2 columns of 23 lines ruled in ink.
note: Manuscript note: Original housing included printed label (with British orthography) suggesting that the full codex dated from the 14th century, was of Carthusian origin and contained nearly 300 leaves.|f. 1r-v: Latin.
acknowledgements: C.W. Dutschke kindly supplied information that made this description possible.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

physical_description: Binding: In limp vellum.|Other decoration, ff. 1-138v: Presently three 7-line painted blue initials on burnished gold grounds (on pages with full border decoration) and nine 4-line painted blue initials (on pages with decorated outside borders).|Script, ff. 1-138v: Gothic.|Layout, ff. 1-138v: Two quires of 6 leaves followed by a singleton, with remaining gatherings of 8 leaves except for final quire of (apparently) 6 leaves; 25 long lines.
note: Bibliography: Bond and Faye, p. 302 (listed as Horae).|ff. 1-138v: Modern foliation in pencil every ten leaves. Single leaves missing after ff. 13v, 37v, 41v, 51v, 61v, 74v, 121v and 138v.|ff. 1-138v: Latin.|ff. 1-138v: Contains calendar (ff. 1-13v), psalms (ff. 14-130) and canticles (ff. 130v-138v). The calendar includes feasts for six bishops of Metz.
acknowledgements: ff. 1-138v: Localization and revised date attribution courtesy of C.W. Dutschke.|ff. 1-138v: Identification of text as ferial Psalter courtesy of C.W. Dutschke.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

physical_description: Binding: Original vellum marked with a Maltese cross and inscribed "Cajon 17 // Num. 114 / 19 Dicembre de 1471."
note: Bibliography: Bond and Faye, p. 303.|ff. 1-2v: Latin.|ff. 1-2v: Through the writ, Pacheco and Portocarrero, founders and supporters of Our Lady of the Sarral, are granted exclusive burial rights for themselves and their descendants in its chapel (with an exception only for King Henry IV), with perpetual daily masses to be said for their souls and with an anniversary service to be observed on the day of St. James. Modern abstract in Spanish is attached.|Explicit, ff. 1-2v: The General of the Order of St. Hieronimus in the Monastery of St. Bartholomew of Lugrana confirms a writ of 2 December made by monks of Our Lady of the Sarral, outside Segovia, involving their patrons Don Juan Pacheco and spouse Dona Maria Portocarrero.|Docket: The General of the Order of St. Hieronimus in the Monastery of St. Bartholomew of Lugrana confirms a writ of 2 December made by monks of Our Lady of the Sarral, outside Segovia, involving their patrons Don Juan Pacheco and spouse Dona Maria Portocarrero.

physical_description: Binding: Old vellum.|Other decoration, ff. 1-40v: Seven initials in burnished gold; one initial, f. 6, with bole only (gold not applied); most other initials in red.|Script, ff. 1-40v: Round gothic; humanistic cursive.|Music, ff. 1-40v: Square notation on 4-line black staves with custos.|Layout, ff. 1-40v: Quires of 8 leaves, most with 4 lines of text and music; ff. 35v-38v with 24 long lines; ink ruling sometimes in black and elsewhere in pale red.
note: ff. 1-40v: Modern foliation in pencil every five leaves.|ff. 1-40v: Latin.|ff. 1-40v: Contents: 1-13v Office of the Dead; 14-20 Feast of the Purification of Mary; 20v-35 Palm Sunday; 35-39 Praises on the Day of the Dead; 39v-40 Text and notes of an antiphon; 40v Notes on the tones of an antiphon using the Sol-fa system.

physical_description: Other decoration, f. 1r-v: Alternating red and blue initials with simple penwork flourishing in the contrasting color.|Script, f. 1r-v: Gothic.|Music, f. 1r-v: Square notation on 4-line red staves with custos.|Layout, f. 1r-v: 10 lines of text and music.
note: f. 1r-v: Latin.
acknowledgements: f. 1r-v: Revised date attribution courtesy of C.W. Dutschke.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
former_owner_as_recorded: Gift in 1975 of Dr. Martin Picker (1929-2005). Earlier call number: Ac. 2834.
physical_description: Other decoration, f. 1r-v: Large blue initial with elaborate red penwork; strapwork initials.|Music, f. 1r-v: Square notation on 5-line red staves with custos.|Layout, f. 1r-v: 7 lines of text and music.
note: f. 1r-v: Latin.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
former_owner_as_recorded: Survived as part of a binding; acquired in 2000 from H.P. Kraus.
physical_description: Other decoration, Fragment: One red initial.|Script, Fragment: Pregothic.|Layout, Fragment: 2 columns presently of 33 lines.
note: Fragment: Portions of inner columns cut away with consequent loss of text.|Fragment: Latin.|Fragment: Contains on recto Judges 16:6-15 in column A and Judges 16:18-26 in column B; on verso: Judges 16:30-17:7 in column A and Judges 17:12-18:7 in column B.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
former_owner_as_recorded: Survived as part of a binding; acquired in 2000 from H.P. Kraus.
physical_description: Other decoration, Fragment: Four or five red initials.|Script, Fragment: Late caroline minuscule.|Layout, Fragment: Presently 13 long lines.
note: Fragment: Lower section of leaf?; verso damaged and all but illegible.|Fragment: Latin.
acknowledgements: C.W. Dutschke kindly supplied information that made this description possible.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
former_owner_as_recorded: Survived as part of a binding; acquired in 2000 from H.P. Kraus.
physical_description: Script, Fragment: Pregothic.|Layout, Fragment: 2 columns presently with 12 lines; ruled in dry point.
note: Fragment: Lower section of one column.|Fragment: Latin.|Fragment: Apparently contains part of story based on apocryphal Acts of Thomas, in section in which Treptia (or Tertia), wife of Misdaeus, speaks with Mygdonia, wife of Charisius. Version of story also recounted by Oderic Vitalis, Historia ecclesiastica(cf. PL188:162A-162C).
acknowledgements: C.W. Dutschke kindly supplied information that made this description possible.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
former_owner_as_recorded: Survived as part of a binding; acquired in 2000 from H.P. Kraus.
physical_description: Other decoration, ff. 1-2v: Alternating red and blue initials, mostly 1-line; single 2-line blue initial with flourishing in red.|Script, ff. 1-2v: Gothic.|Music, ff. 1-2v: Square notation on 4-line red staves.|Layout, ff. 1-2v: 23 long lines (when music not present).
note: ff. 1-2v: Both leaves cropped at outer margin, with partial loss of some initials; worm holes; f. 1v noticeably damaged from use in binding.|ff. 1-2v: Latin.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
former_owner_as_recorded: Survived as part of a binding; acquired in 2000 from H.P. Kraus.
physical_description: Other decoration, ff. 1-2v: 2-line initials alternating in red (with blue flourishing?) and, presumably, in blue (with red flourishing), although all blue ink now gone.|Script, ff. 1-2v: Gothic.|Layout, ff. 1-2v: 2 columns with 31 lines.
note: ff. 1-2v: Bifolium lacking portions of gutter and other margins.|ff. 1-2v: Latin.|ff. 1-2v: Votive masses: for a friend, for the health of those who are alive, for rain, for good weather, to repel temptation, for the living and the dead, in honor of Peter and Paul, in honor of all saints written by Innocent IV, against the persecutors of the church, for peace, for the pope, for those who travel, for the sick.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
former_owner_as_recorded: Survived as part of a binding; acquired in 2000 from H.P. Kraus.
physical_description: Other decoration, 3 fragments: Red and blue initials.|Script, 3 fragments: Gothic.|Layout, 3 fragments: 2 columns presently with up to 37 lines of text; gloss in 2 columns presently of ca. 80 lines.
note: 3 fragments: Three leaves trimmed at three edges, including two adhered to leaves of early printed text; spots of other adhered material; some ink loss.|3 fragments: Latin.|3 fragments: Gloss text is the Glossa ordinariaof Accursius.
acknowledgements: 3 fragments: Text identification courtesy of Dr. Thomas Izbicki.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
former_owner_as_recorded: Survived as part of a binding; acquired in 2000 from H.P. Kraus.
physical_description: Other decoration, ff. 1-2v: One red initial; space reserved for a 3-line initial.|Script, ff. 1-2v: Pregothic.|Layout, ff. 1-2v: 2 columns presently of 39 lines; ruled in dry point.
note: ff. 1-2v: Trimmed bifolium with loss of half a column on each leaf and no more than a few lines at bottom; worm holes; minor damp staining.|ff. 1-2v: Latin.
acknowledgements: C.W. Dutschke kindly supplied information that made this description possible.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
former_owner_as_recorded: Survived as part of a binding; acquired in 2000 from H.P. Kraus.
physical_description: Other decoration, ff. 1-2v: 4-line initials in red and blue with penwork in the contrasting color.|Script, ff. 1-2v: Gothic.|Layout, ff. 1-2v: 2 columns of 49 lines.
note: ff. 1-2v: Loss of text from trimming and worm holes; all leaves darkened. Origin in northeast Italy suggested by orthography.|ff. 1-2v: Latin.|ff. 1-2v: Captions reference edition by Nathaniel Edward Griffin (Cambridge: Medieval Academy of America, 1936).
acknowledgements: ff. 1-2v: Text identification courtesy of C.W. Dutschke.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
former_owner_as_recorded: Survived as part of a binding; acquired in 2000 from H.P. Kraus.
physical_description: Binding: Not bound.|Script, ff. 1-4v: Cursive gothic.|Layout, ff. 1-4v: 2 columns of 32-33 lines.
note: ff. 1-4v: Two damaged bifolia: worm holes, damp stains and adhered material.|ff. 1-4v: Latin.|ff. 1-4v: Contains sermons or outlines of sermons for Eastertide (days near Passion Sunday, Palm Sunday, Maundy Thursday, Good Friday); cf. doubling of a column for lists, e.g., on f. 1, col. a: Gentium; Supplicium; Premium; and then Sequendo; Timendo; Querendo.
acknowledgements: C.W. Dutschke kindly supplied information that made this description possible.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
title_as_recorded: Commentaries on Acts of the Apostles
former_owner_as_recorded: Acquired in 2000 from H.P. Kraus.

note: ff. 1-18v: Foliated as 74-83, 135-142.|ff. 1-18v: Latin.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
former_owner_as_recorded: Survived as part of a binding; acquired in 2000 from H.P. Kraus.
physical_description: Other decoration, f. 1r-v: Large painted initial; 2-line red initial with blue penwork flourishing; evidence of red penwork on verso.|Script, f. 1r-v: Gothic.|Layout, f. 1r-v: 2 columns of 38 lines.
note: f. 1r-v: Worm holes; verso presently all but blank.|f. 1r-v: Latin.|f. 1r-v: Contains Galatians 6:6-18, prologue to Ephesians, and Ephesians 1:1-13.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

note: ff. 1, 2, 3, 4: Text on one side only. Also, two of the four leaves lack sections of parchment with consequent loss of text.|ff. 1, 2, 3, 4: Latin.|ff. 1, 2, 3, 4: Contains homilies for various times of the year.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

note: ff. 1-2v: Versos all but blank, with only traces of red ink remaining; other losses largely confined to part of one column (f. 1).|ff. 1-2v: Latin.|ff. 1-2v: Contains epistle and gospel readings, with prayers.
